Some of the documents considered in the preparation of this report were originally in

[Opening Statement.docx, p.1]
Gulfstream never revised its promised RTS date.

[Bassim Draft Witness Statement.docx, p.1]
In summary, CITIOM entrusted its Aircraft to Gulfstream, the OEM, for a major inspection based on a proposal that proved to be grossly misleading in terms of cost and downtime. Gulfstream failed to utilize its own data and expertise to provide a realistic estimate, failed to properly manage the project, suffered from significant staffing and efficiency issues at its St. Louis facility, failed to adequately address corrosion issues from prior maintenance, and ultimately caused CITIOM significant financial and operational damages through extraordinary delays and cost overruns. Their failure to meet the repeatedly promised June 21, 2024 return date directly caused the collapse of a lucrative sale agreement, resulting in a further loss of approximately $1 million upon the eventual sale of the Aircraft.

[1. Joe Rivera - Cross Exam & Impeachment .docx, p.1]
Highlight that internal updates (e.g., GAC0039521) repeatedly promised fixes that never materialized.

[1-66.pdf, p.5]
▪ July 10th, 2024: We were promised improvement on part availability to August 26th,
